WRITING.TITLE: Draping practice from the other day #10024;

WRITING.TEXT: The fabric is chiffon, I draped these on a dress form with pins and creative thinking lol. I #8217;ll be using one of these drapes as inspiration for my final evening wear project #128519;

WRITING.TITLE: Silk dress with slit! Question about drafting straight necklines??? #10024;

WRITING.TEXT: So, I made this dress the other day out of polyester looking silk fabric and added eyelash trim, I used personalized blocks and retraced them into this style. My question is: how do you draft straight neckline dresses? I always end up with a dip and it doesn #8217;t sit flush against the skin? My block might be outdated so I #8217;m going to try updating and see if that makes a difference, if you have any ideas please let me know! #128151;

Thank you #128591; #127995; It was a full bodice with a bust dart that I kept and the dress does have an interfaced facing. I know princess seams would be a solution but I #8217;m trying to learn how to draft a straight neckline with bust darts, I #8217;ve seen lot of stuff online in similar fabrics with a clean fit, it #8217;s a struggle lol
Ooh that #8217;s a great idea! I #8217;ll try measuring how wide I want it on myself before drafting!Thank you! #128591; #127995; #128522;

I made this for one of my uni classes, this is the sample although anything that #8217;s pink will stay in the same material. I drafted this myself with instructions from my prof so I can #8217;t really post a how-to but I #8217;ll try to find the book she used! I included the technical so it was a little bit more clear #10024; Link to the book: https://www.amazon.com/Bare-Essentials-Construction-Drafting-Lingerie/dp/0983132860

I did! You can start by going to a store in person or online and picking it by your bra size (like 32A or something) but it works out best if you hold it up to yourself and see if it fits before buying #128522;
Yup, you have to buy (or make) underwire channeling that you sew to the bra and then slide the wire into!

Thank you #128519; #128591; #127995; It #8217;s pretty good even though it looks kind of off in the pic, I had a critique for it today and just have to take in the top half of the cup a tiny bit! You should! It #8217;s so fun #129303;
Awe thanks! #128151; #128519; you should go for it, it #8217;s a lot easier to make then it looks and there #8217;s lots of great tutorials online #129303;

Thank you! #9786; #65039; Everyone should try it once, it #8217;s nice for using up scrap fabrics too! It #8217;s super comfy, I used a thicker foam than I should have but I don #8217;t regret it lol, using your own measurements definitely helps!
Do it! It #8217;s worth a try #128519;
That #8217;s the plan! This is the test one so I didn #8217;t wanna use my final straps and stuff on it, I #8217;ll post the final piece when it #8217;s finished #128519; #128591; #127995;
You should! I noticed when I was shopping for underwire there was a larger selection (no pun intended) for larger sizes
I bought mine at a local store in my city, I can #8217;t remember the name, but https://www.braandcorsetsupplies.com has a really great selection!
That #8217;s good to know, I can #8217;t imagine what a higher pile velvet would be like #128565; I was planning on using it more as a lingerie only piece though #128131; #127997;
I buy the wires separately in a store in my city, but you can buy them online here! https://www.braandcorsetsupplies.com/product-category/underwires-and-casings/
When you sew the bottom half to the top half it automatically curves into a more dome like shape, which maintains the space #128522;

Ordering bra supplies online is fun and honestly easier then shopping in a physical store, because there #8217;s a lot of bits and pieces you need to make one. For the foam cups I made my own by cutting out my original pattern, minus the seam allowance and zigzagged them together (like press the foam side by side and zigzag stitch along the line). I totally agree! You can make one out scraps and a couple extra pieces for sooo cheap! I think the most difficult part was sewing the underwire channeling in, if you zoom in you can see my stitches get wobbly, but this was my first sample so for my final I #8217;m just going to take it really slow, other than that it was pretty easy! #9786; #65039;

This page looks pretty good https://www.foundationsrevealed.com/bra-making/165-bras-drafting-a-darted-cup if you scroll down a bit they have some good drafting instructions, if that doesn #8217;t work, I would highly suggest trying out a book, the one I linked should cover the basics #128519;

That #8217;s true, the pattern I was originally instructed to make had no seam lines in the bottom or the top, but I added a style line to the top half (not a far or anything). I have a smaller bust so maybe that #8217;s why it looks strange, If you had a larger bust you had to slash and spread the bottom and top pieces #128591; #127995;
You can put seams anywhere along the top or bottom when drafting, I have a small-medium bust so this shape works well #128522;
I love that #128514;

Did you use underwire channeling? I started by sewing the top half of that and then rotated it and sewed a few stitches at the top of where the wire would hit and then rotated again to sew the bottom half #128591; #127995;
Hmm #129300; I sewed mine on the wrong side, did you you pin yours down? I tried to make sure to stretch the fabric out a bit so it wouldn #8217;t get caught up in the stitches, I hope this helps!
Honestly!
My mom is a triple D and she wants me to make her a bra, so I #8217;ll try posting about that when I do! #128522;
Np! #128519; If you have any more questions, feel free to ask!
Thank you!! #9786; #65039; You should! The velvet #8217;s pretty thin (in between an 1/8-1/4 thick)
Lol good idea, apparently you should be looking for laminated foam? That #8217;s what #8217;s my prof told me #129335; #127996; #8205; #9792; #65039;
No hurt in trying! It #8217;s pretty quick to whip up, due to the small pieces #128519;
Wow, how much are they where you live? #128565; I got my pair for $3, but that #8217;s a good idea especially if you grab some at a thrift store!
No you #8217;re right, I wouldn #8217;t pay that much! That #8217;s a really cool idea #128591; #127995;

Hey everyone this is sort of a pt.2 after my bra post! Here is the matching underwear, this is the sample so *colours and materials will change*! Also I #8217;m making this for a uni class! The fabric and notions are from multiple shops around my city (I #8217;d rather keep that info private tho) here #8217;s a shop online that has lots of lingerie supplies: https://www.braandcorsetsupplies.com I drafted this myself using a panty block that I drafted from my profs instructions, this tutorial is very similar though: http://www.timelace-studio.com/how-to-draft-a-basic-panty-pattern/ tutorial for making garter belts: https://www.ohhhlululingerie.com/2017/02/10/valentines-sew-along-a-garter-belt-two-ways/ And for the waist part I just held the bra strap elastic around my waist and then sewed it into a circle, attaching it to the underwear w/a another piece of strap #128519;
Thank you!! I actually plan to open one this summer, I wanna try selling some custom lingerie pieces! #128149;

This was self drafted using blocks from my uni as a base, feel free to ask questions about how I drafted, it #8217;s easier for me to type it out that way! I #8217;m a second year fashion design student btw #128131; #127997; For the top: -I made the turtle neck by measuring the neck (front and back) and drew a rectangle from that measurement -cut the arm piece in half and slash and spread the bottom half to create a flare -then serged it altogether For the bottoms: -this tutorials covers pretty much all of the things I did https://www.google.ca/amp/s/wkdesigner.wordpress.com/2008/10/07/classic-jeans/amp/ -but I made mine wide legged lol These were inspired by scooby doo (colour palette/70s vibe). Also the materials are from local shops. I #8217;m really happy with how they turned out, just handed them in today! #128519;
Lol, Noo that #8217;s just the light reflecting off of the velvet
Thank you, that #8217;s so sweet of you to say! #128149;
I don #8217;t, but I #8217;ll probably post that when I have the final product done!
Ooh thank you! That #8217;s a greats idea actually!
Thank you, me too lol #128591; #127995;
Awee thank you, I #8217;m glad you liked it #128149; #128149;

Yes! It #8217;s so hard finding different colours in physical stores! I had to dye the bra strap elastic I #8217;ll be using in my final pieces to match, although it ended up being more on the purple side, but if I had time I would have ordered from Etsy! They have the best selection, colour wise IMO #128591; #127995;

Anytime! #128149; I have a sewing tutorial channel on YouTube, if you search #8216;Bella Dupuis #8217; it should be the first thing to show up. I don #8217;t have lingerie videos up yet but I plan on posting some in less than a month, when I #8217;m done school! #128591; #127995;

Awe thank you #128149;

Idk if I #8217;m going to do a tutorial on these buuut I #8217;m gonna do tutorials for lingerie basics (which u could use to make these), just because I #8217;m thinking of an Etsy store and these would probably be in it #128519;
Awee, this is so lovely!! It must have taken a lot of time!
Looks so professional #128079; #127996; #128562;

Hi everyone! So this is how my lingerie final set turned out! This was for one of my second year uni classes, I #8217;m super happy with it, other than how I dyed the straps! They look really blue grey in the photos but they #8217;re much more purple-nude-grey in real life lol, which is closer to the velvet #127775; This was really fun to make, not super expensive and if you mess up 1/2 yard of fabric goes a longgg way! Also, if you want to know how this was made, just check out my last 2 posts with the samples!! #128151;
Thank you so much! #128519; #128151;

I used dylon? (Pretty sure) and mixed the flamingo pink and a nude pink, I paint a lot and know about colour mixing so I probably could #8217;ve thought about a better mix but that stuff is expensive!

I #8217;m not sure, I haven #8217;t tried them on with stockings yet. The ones I have, have the sticky stay up edge so I might not be able to tell, but I #8217;ll test it out and let you know when I get them back from marking lol

WRITING.TITLE: My first lingerie design! #9889; #65039; #128151;
WRITING.TEXT: I would love to hear everyone #8217;s opinions on my first lingerie set! I was gonna try crossposting but I guess it #8217;s only text post here, I #8217;m new lol #128522; [lingerie set posted in r/sewing](https://www.reddit.com/r/sewing/comments/bcd07a/lingerie_set_done_selfdrafted/?utm_source=share amp;utm_medium=ios_app)

Thank youuu #128151; #128151; The opaque part on the underwear was originally meant to be mesh but I couldn #8217;t find a colour match and didn #8217;t want to dye it, but I like how the silk turned out better #128129; #127995; #8205; #9792; #65039;
Awe that #8217;s so sweet #128151;

Thank you! Yea I get that, my mom said she would prefer little ribbons to age it up for herself lol and the non matching colours was because I suck at dyeing things #128514; Thank you, it was easier than I thought it would be!!
Hahaha #128514; thank you
I got it from a local shop in my city, but you can find it anywhere really #128591; #127995; #128519;
I used a zigzag stitch (to maintain stretch) for pretty much everything, but switched to a straight stitch when sewing on the straps!
Thank youu #128591; #127995; It #8217;s never to late to get a new one haha

I had to take in the top seam and cut off some of the top of the foam cup and then for the under I just had to cut some excess off to make more of a cheeky style! I think the the cradle turned out so small because I have a small torso but a medium-large bust so the cups took up a fair amount of room, but I know that can be change in drafting, I #8217;d have to try it myself to figure it out though. Don #8217;t be intimidated, 1/2 yard of fabric, in lingerie making goes a longgg way! So if you make a mistake you have a couple of chances to try again, and making a sample is always helpful! Also, sometimes the fixes can be intuitive, if something #8217;s to big you know you need to take it in #128591; #127995; and thank you #9786; #65039; #128591; #127995;
I #8217;m gonna be making some YouTube videos about lingerie making this summer #128519;
Ooh I might try to find some red versions of the fabric #128559; and thank you! #128519;
Thank you #128591; #127995; #128519; practice makes perfect!!

Hey everyone #128151; I just finished this swimsuit inspired by this @labambaswim (on IG) set: https://labambaswim.com/products/la-pantera-bikini?variant=27673111789670 I drafted using a pattern block I had made in school, but this tutorial should do the trick of you #8217;d like to make your own: https://www.foundationsrevealed.com/index-of-articles/bra-making/how-to-make-a-bra/161-bras-determining-your-size And I used a similar (if not the same) block as this one, for the bottoms: http://www.timelace-studio.com/how-to-draft-a-basic-panty-pattern/ Any pattern alterations were made by eye and tweaked when I made a sample #128519; #128591; #127995; also I used foam and cut it out of the bra cup pattern to create padding and used underwire! All of of materials were from local shops, although I #8217;d rather keep the location private, but you find everything on Etsy! For the first time I made ribbon labels, which everyone should try, it #8217;s such a perfect finishing touch! #128519;
Thank you, I really appreciate that! #128151; #128591; #127995; Good idea, the freedom of making your own stuff is so nice!! Have you thought of a bustier shape to conceal it?

Thank you so much! #128522; I used a stretch needle and a 2-3 width zigzag to sew things together, a straight on any visible seams and for the bottoms I used a twin stretch needle with a normal straight stitch too!

Hey everyone, I just finished this summer dress, cause it #8217;s starting to warm up here in Canada #128151; How I made it: The skirt was a basic circle skirt with an extras 2 inches added around the waist for buttons #129303; I used this calculator to keep things easy: https://byhandlondon.com/pages/circle-skirt-app Also the sleeves were made the same way but I measured the armhole instead of my waist! And for the top I used a bodice block that I made here: https://patternlab.london/lab/shop/blocks I #8217;ll start with back, because it #8217;s easier but I didn #8217;t change much other than add a line of gathers to the bottom, only because the skirt and bodice weren #8217;t the same size, to I had to cinch the back in. Then for the front, it was tough lol. I started by moving the dart to the waist line. Then I drew a perpendicular line from the waist dart tip across the bodice, I folded it along that line and drew in the underbust shape just on the bottom section, unfolded that (added notches 1/3 apart) and then cut along the new style line. Next I taped close the dart of the new bottom piece and that piece was done. For the top half I x #8217;ed out the bottom dart and drew gather marks along where the dart was to the notch marks. For the shoulder tucks, I drew a perpendicular line from where the dart tip from before was to the neckline (also drew in the new v-neckline and x #8217;ed out excess), then from that line I drew to lines going into the shoulder equally space apart and at a visually pleasing angle. Cut those 2 lines just a few hairs away from the first line, then carefully cut the 3rd horizontal line open (you might need tape to keep the corners of the line together). Open the 2 vertical lines as wide as you want while pulling down the horizontal line, gently and tape all down on a new piece of paper. Trace around that and you have your new pattern piece! That #8217;s pretty much it, if u have any questions, lemme know! (Also I will be posting a video tutorial on my channel for this soon, if you #8217;d like to see it you can dm me for the link, I #8217;m not sure if this counts as self promo so feel free to tell me to edit this part out!)
I watch your channel, so proud of you girl! The piece looks great #10024; #128171;

(I #8217;ll be posting a tutorial on my channel just dm me for a link!) I started by drafting a block for the pants, using this book: https://bit.ly/2DYmdJt Then I added a pleat to the front (but no I think a long tuck would have looked better), drew up pockets, one slanted for a slash pocket, a fly facing and fly shield and then a waistband! If you have any more questions don #8217;t be afraid to ask #128151; #129419; *fabric was on sale at fabricland #128129; #127995; #8205; #9792; #65039;*

Hey everyone!! #128151; I just finished this dress and it #8217;s soo fun to wear, there #8217;s almost 8 metres of fabric on the bottom tier! #128565; So here #8217;s how I did it: I cut 2 circle skirts (1 lining and one self fabric) Then I cut the bottom tier pieces in sections of 48 x 13, I ended up using 3! I just gathered it to fit along the bottom and then sewed on an eyelet trim, the skirt was heavily inspired by this post: [inspo](https://www.instagram.com/p/BsCkRJFHs2Z/?igshid=gxepxngqq9xi) For the bodice I started out with a bodice block from here, (they #8217;re making u pay for the pdf #8217;s now:( but I still think it #8217;s a good investment: https://patternlab.london/lab/ And did something like this: https://corsetmakers.livejournal.com/1341668.html Then drew the sweetheart shape on the bodice! Finally I added straps and the front tie (the bodice was also lined). The fabric and trim is from fabricland! I just wanted to add a little comment/question, do you guys ever make something and not really know what occasion it #8217;s for, like whether or not it #8217;s too fancy or too casual? I #8217;d like to wear this dress on days out in the summer but I #8217;m not sure if it #8217;s too much?

I just gathered it to fit along the bottom and then sewed on an eyelet trim, the skirt was heavily inspired by this post: [inspo](https://www.instagram.com/p/BsCkRJFHs2Z/?igshid=gxepxngqq9xi) For the bodice I started out with a bodice block from here, (they #8217;re making u pay for the pdf #8217;s now:( but I still think it #8217;s a good investment: https://patternlab.london/lab/ And did something like this: https://corsetmakers.livejournal.com/1341668.html Then drew the sweetheart shape on the bodice! Hey everyone #128151; I just made this wrap dress with a tulip style skirt and lining, I #8217;ve tried to make wrap dresses in the past and the fit always ended up being a mess, but this time I think it worked out pretty well #128591; #127995; and side note even the one I bought had some fit issues, I prefer using woven fabrics but I think using a stretch fabric would be 10x easier! I bought the fabric on sale from fabricland, a striped rayon and some white lining fabric for underneath. How I made it: Bodice: Made bodice block from here: https://patternlab.london/lab/shop/blocks into a v-neck shape and slashed from the dart tip 90 degrees to the v-neckline and cut along the middle of the dart, rotating the slash closed 1/2 #8221;, this really helps prevent gapping in the bust area that normally happens with wrap dresses! (I lined the front bodice pieces with the self fabric) And I cut 1 1/2 #8221; straps. Skirt: Used blocks I made from here: Skirt block tutorial: https://www.google.ca/search?q=how+to+draft+skirt+block amp;rlz=1C5CHFA_enCA773CA773 amp;oq=how+to+draft+skirt+ amp;aqs=chrome.2.0j69i57j0l4.5381j0j7 amp;sourceid=chrome amp;ie=UTF-8#kpvalbx=1 Link to the skirt block video: https://youtu.be/ChjKiKcpDGM and just lengthened the back skirt, then cut 2 front skirt pieces and cut the rounded tulip shape. Then I added a short skirt lining underneath using the same blocks. And added ties to the bodice, creating a hole in one of the side seams to loop the tie that is underneath the dress, through to the other side.
Awe thank you!!

Oh wow that #8217;s awesome!! And thank you, you #8217;re right it takes a lot of planning and patience to avoid that homemade, crafty look! That #8217;s so true, sergers really make it 10x easier to get that clean finish inside, if anyone wants to see the inside I can share lol #128591; #127995;

WRITING.TITLE: I made this summer wrap dress from scratch! #127754;

WRITING.TEXT: I #8217;ll post it in a comment #128151; #128591; #127995; one second!

Hey everyone #128151; I just made this wrap dress with a tulip style skirt and lining, I #8217;ve tried to make wrap dresses in the past and the fit always ended up being a mess, but this time I think it worked out pretty well #128591; #127995; and side note even the one I bought had some fit issues, I prefer using woven fabrics but I think using a stretch fabric would be 10x easier! I bought the fabric on sale from fabricland, a striped rayon and some white lining fabric for underneath. How I made it: Bodice: Made bodice block from here: https://patternlab.london/lab/shop/blocks into a v-neck shape and slashed from the dart tip 90 degrees to the v-neckline and cut along the middle of the dart, rotating the slash closed 1/2 #8221;, this really helps prevent gapping in the bust area that normally happens with wrap dresses! (I lined the front bodice pieces with the self fabric) And I cut 1 1/2 #8221; straps. Skirt: Used blocks I made from here: Skirt block tutorial: https://www.google.ca/search?q=how+to+draft+skirt+block amp;rlz=1C5CHFA_enCA773CA773 amp;oq=how+to+draft+skirt+ amp;aqs=chrome.2.0j69i57j0l4.5381j0j7 amp;sourceid=chrome amp;ie=UTF-8#kpvalbx=1 Link to the skirt block video: https://youtu.be/ChjKiKcpDGM and just lengthened the back skirt, then cut 2 front skirt pieces and cut the rounded tulip shape. Then I added a short skirt lining underneath using the same blocks. And added ties to the bodice, creating a hole in one of the side seams to loop the tie that is underneath the dress, through to the other side.

WRITING.TITLE: [Self-drafted] Smocked gingham tube top + my workspace! #128151;

WRITING.TEXT: Hey everyone #128151; Hope you enjoy my workspace and me posing like a mom of 4 who owns a successful Etsy account! (Who doesn #8217;t aspire to be that though??). I made this tube top the other day and all I have to say is smocking is a lot of work! Wow, I cut about a 1.5 metres of fabric by 13 #8221; on fold and then cut the fold so I would have 2 rectangles, then I used elastic thread in the bobbin to create the smocking effect. It took forever and my hands hurt but I #8217;m happy with the end result, so that #8217;s all that counts #8212;right? #128517; Also the fabric is a pink gingham cotton from fabricland!

Awe thank you!! #9786; #65039; #128151; It took me 2 days to make so not forever but definitely repetitive, I still recommend giving it a go though! Also if anyone wants to try this buy at least 4 spools of elastic!
Haha thank you! I #8217;m not sure what else to post, close-ups maybe? #128517;
Lol thank you!! #128151;

Hey everyone! #128151; I made this bra a few weeks ago and have been meaning to hate it! I used a block pattern that was given to me by one of my professors so I can #8217;t share that due to copyright reasons but here #8217;s a really good tutorial: (http://foundationsrevealed.com/bra-making/165-bras-drafting-a-darted-cup) All the materials I used were from fabricland, a local fabric liquidation place and the hardware was from a fabric store in Toronto, The straps and lace were hand dyed, although I wish they a warmer tone and I completely forgot to dye the clasps lol. I ended up having to use these attached triangle bikini cups for the cups (due to lack of options at a reasonable price) but I angled them on their sides so the rounded edge was on top and the point was on the bottom, then trimmed the pointed edge off and rounded it out. I draped the gathering on the cups and sewed it down with my machine and completed the rest of the bra like normal #128591; #127995;
Lol #128514;thank you!! You #8217;re very kind #128519; #128151;

Yes, most projects take me 2-3 days including drafting. I #8217;ve been sewing since I was 10, but I #8217;m 20 now and would say I #8217;ve been sewing/drafting #8220;properly #8221; for the past 4 years! Uni has really helped!
Thank you! #128151;Marie Antoinette/rococo is a huge inspiration for me I find it easier, although perfecting comfort and shape can be tricky!

So I did make the pattern but I used a block I drafted myself. When drafting people use a basic block and cut/slash spread to create the style they #8217;ve designed. To draft completely from scratch I use my measurements and draw out the block, but once you have the basic block there #8217;s no point in remaking it every time because it #8217;s the base you #8217;ll always use. For this piece I did draft the block myself a while ago and then I made some minor changes to achieve this style. I #8217;m bad at explaining things but I hope that made some sense!

WRITING.TITLE: [Self-drafted] Managed to make this dress before midterms #128517;

WRITING.TEXT: So I made this dress for my boyfriend #8217;s mom #8217;s wedding! The fabric is from a store in Toronto, as well as rose gold rings and sliders I used for the straps. I used blocks from here for the bodice as my base: [bodice](https://patternlab.london/home/) And I used this book to make and alter the skirt block: [skirt](https://www.amazon.com/Pattern-Cutting-Winifred-published-Wiley-Blackwell/dp/B00E28OAV6) Also, I used an invisible zipper in the back, did an invisible hem? (If that #8217;s what it #8217;s called), and I finished the slit by sewing on interfacing sticky side up then turning in and ironing to get a clean finish (my prof taught me this trick #128131; #127997;).
Thank you! No, they just happened to match almost exactly, I actually bought the fabric after the tie but we knew we were looking for this kind of colour!
